did.unittitle: Historical Center for the Health Sciences (University of Michigan) records 1831-1992
did.abstract: University of Michigan unit established in 1990 in part to collect and disseminate information regarding the history of health sciences in Michigan. Records include newsletter of the Center; collected historical manuscripts, photographs, and motion pictures relating to the development of health sciences at the University of Michigan; include notebooks of medical school students, account book, 1831-1839, of Berrien Springs, Michigan physician, and miscellaneous materials relating to the medical school and to medical practice.

bioghist.p: The Historical Center for the Health Sciences (HCHS) was founded in January 1990 at the University of Michigan for the purpose of "fostering broader understanding and deeper appreciation of the pioneering role taken by the University and the State of Michigan to advance knowledge of disease and promote human health" (Retrospectives, Spring 1992).

Through the efforts of Director Nicholas Steneck, HCHS has begun a ten-year campaign to establish a major program to serve the university and the state of Michigan by collecting and disseminating information regarding the history of health sciences in Michigan via lectures and conferences, and the publication of research guides, monographs, and its newsletter Retrospectives.
For more information regarding the activities and publications of HCHS, the researcher should consult the inaugural issue of Retrospectives (Spring 1992) located in Box 1 of the collection.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Historical Center for Health Sciences (HCHS) measure .6 linear feet. The records include a small file of administrative records documenting operation of the center and archival material collected by the center. The materials have been divided into two subgroups: Administrative and Collections.

scopecontent.p: The first subgroup, Administrative, consists of one series, Printed Materials. The Printed Materials series consists of HCHS's newsletter Retrospectives, first issued in Spring 1992.

The second subgroup, Collections, consists of materials gathered together from a variety of sources by HCHS. These materials have been divided into three series reflecting the format of the records: Manuscripts, Photographs, and Films.

Within each series in the Collections subgroup, the materials are arranged by Survey Numbers assigned by HCHS to control information in its database. A printout of these database records, also arranged by Survey Number, is attached to the end of the contents list. The researcher should consult the printout of database records for a more detailed description of each item and information regarding an item's acquisition by HCHS.
Each of the folders contains the item(s) listed in the boxlist as well as any correspondence (generally between the donor and HCHS Director Nicholas Steneck) generated regarding the item(s).

The Manuscripts series contains a variety of material, including student notebooks from the late nineteenth century and early twentieth century and correspondence regarding medical issues. The account book of Dr. Samuel Castle Bartholomew, of Berrien Springs, Michigan, contains notes regarding his housecalls to patients in addition to financial information.

scopecontent.p: The series of Photographs consists primarily of photographs of early Medical School faculty. Also included are photographs of the Peterson Hospital and of the Phi Chi house (UM medical fraternity). The Peterson Hospital was founded by Dr. Reuben Peterson of UM in 1902 and was renamed the Ann Arbor Private Hospital in 1917.
